bio:treatment.description: Annuals, biennials, or perennials (shrubs in A. californica, subshrubs in A. nesiotica); usually fibrous-rooted, sometimes taprooted, caudices sometimes woody, rhizomes sometimes present. Stems usually not wandlike (wandlike in A. californica, A. nesiotica, A. palmeri). Leaves usually deciduous, rarely persistent, basal (rosettes) and/or cauline (not in fascicles). Heads usually disciform (discoid in A. nesiotica and A. palmeri). Receptacles glabrous (paleate in A. palmeri). Florets: usually peripheral 3–20 pistillate and fertile (0 pistillate in A. nesiotica, A. palmeri); central (or all) 14–70 bisexual and fertile; corollas funnelform.
sporadic in South America and northern Africa.

verbatim.text: Species ca. 220 (27 in the flora): widespread in Northern Hemisphere, especially North America, Europe, and central and northern Asia, sporadic in South America and northern Africa.

parsed.distribution: widespread in Northern Hemisphere, especially North America, Europe, and central and northern Asia, sporadic in South America and northern Africa.

references.reference: Estes, J. R. 1969. Evidence for autoploid evolution in the Artemisia ludoviciana complex of the Pacific Northwest. Brittonia 21: 29–43.
Keck, D. D. 1946. A revision of the Artemisia vulgaris complex in North America. Proc. Calif. Acad. Sci., ser. 4, 25: 421–468.

key_statement.description: Subshrubs or shrubs (stems wandlike).
Plants 100–350 cm; leaves relatively deeply and coarsely pinnately lobed (lobes 3–7+; coastal California and Baja California)
Plants 10–250 cm; leaves pinnately lobed or 3-lobed.
Shrubs (20–250 cm); leaves pinnately lobed (lobes 0.5–1 mm wide); California (chaparral)
Subshrubs (10–60 cm, stems mostly prostrate); leaves 3-lobed (lobes 1–2 mm wide); Channel Islands, California
Annuals, biennials, perennials, subshrubs, or shrubs (stems sometimes brittle, not wandlike).
Annuals or biennials; leaves among heads (relatively deeply) lobed.
Annuals, 30–200(–300) cm, sweetly aromatic; leaves 2–3-pinnatifid; arrays of heads 10–20 cm diam
Annuals or biennials, (10–)30–80(–150) cm, not aromatic; leaves 1–2-pinnately lobed; arrays of heads 2–4 cm diam
Perennials, subshrubs, or shrubs; leaves among heads mostly entire.
Perennials, subshrubs, or shrubs (not rhizomatous).
Heads in capitate or dense, corymbiform arrays (plants cespitose).
Leaves pinnately lobed; involucres 3–5 mm diam.; phyllaries lanceolate to ovate (margins white)
Leaves 1–2-palmatifid; involucres 3.5–11 mm diam.; phyllaries lanceolate (margins brown or white).
Involucres 3.5–6 × 6–11 mm; phyllaries lanceolate (margins brown); corollas yellow or reddish black, glabrous or glandular (not pilose)
Involucres 3–4 × 3.5–5 mm; phyllaries lanceolate (margins white); corollas yellow, glabrous or pilose
Heads in paniculiform or racemiform arrays (plants not cespitose).
Leaves entire, irregularly palmatifid, or palmately 3-lobed to 2-ternately lobed.
Pappi coroniform; Idaho, Nevada, Oregon
Pappi 0; Alberta, British Columbia, Northwest Territories, Nunavut; Alaska, Washington.
Plants 15–70 cm; leaves palmately 3-lobed to 2-ternately lobed
Plants (5–)10–40 cm; leaves 1–3-palmately lobed
Leaves 2–3-pinnatifid.
Perennials or subshrubs, 50–170 cm (widely branched, stems brittle); leaf lobes less than 1 mm wide; heads erect; involucres 1.5–3 mm diam. (gardens, waste places, much of North America)
Perennials, 10–50 cm (erect, stems not brittle); leaf lobes 1+ mm wide (margins coarsely toothed); heads nodding; involucres 4–10 mm diam.
Peduncles 0 or to 10 mm
Peduncles to 50 mm
Perennials (usually rhizomatous, stems sometimes woody at bases).
Leaves entire, serrate, toothed, or lobed (sinuses to 1 / 2 blade widths).
Plants 20–50(–80, rarely more) cm.
Leaves usually entire, sometimes toothed or lobed; involucres 4–5 mm diam.
Leaves usually lobed, sometimes entire; involucres (1–)2–5 mm diam.
Involucres 2–4(–5.5) mm; phyllaries (gray-green) densely tomentose
Involucres 3.5–4 mm; phyllaries (violet-brown) sparsely tomentose (w North America)
Plants 50–300 cm.
Phyllaries glabrous or sparsely hairy (coast, n California to British Columbia)
Phyllaries usually densely hairy.
Leaves densely hairy (both faces, broadly lanceolate, mostly entire, the proximal lobed; w North America, mostly inland grasslands)
Leaves (bicolor) hairy abaxially, glabrate or glabrous adaxially.
Leaves serrate (teeth ca. 2 mm; inland grasslands and barren areas, high plains)
Leaves mostly deeply lobed (lobes 4–20 mm; mostly e North America, introduced w coast)
Leaves (relatively deeply) lobed (sinuses 1 / 2 + blade widths).
Leaves not bicolor (both faces bright green or silvery), lobes acute or rounded.
Leaves silver-gray, lobes rounded (coastal dunes)
Leaves bright green, lobes acute (not coastal dunes).
Involucres (4–)5–8 × 4–10 mm; 0–3800 m
Leaves bicolor (abaxial faces silvery, adaxial green), lobes acute.
Plants 30–100 cm, lemon-scented; heads usually erect (subalpine and alpine)
Plants 15–70 cm, not lemon-scented; heads usually nodding.
Perennials (widely spreading, stems brittle); garden escapes, c, e North America
Biennials or perennials (erect).
Leaves pinnatifid (lobes 3–5, 0.5–1 mm wide); grasslands or deserts, 600– 2900 m
Leaves 2–3-pinnately lobed (lobes elliptic, 2–6 mm wide); w mountains, 2200–3100 m
